title: Sakura, Chiba
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Chiba%20Prefecture">Chiba Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. , the city had an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 173,740 in 78,483 households and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 1700 persons per km2. The total area of the city is .
Geography.
Sakura is located in northeastern Chiba Prefecture on the <a href="Shim%C5%8Dsa%20Plateau">Shimōsa Plateau</a>. It is situated approximately 40 kilometers northeast of <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> and 15 kilometers from <a href="Narita%20International%20Airport">Narita International Airport</a>. <a href="Chiba%20City">Chiba City</a>, the prefectural capital, lies 15 kilometers southwest of Sakura. Lake Inba forms the northern city limits.
Neighboring municipalities.
Chiba Prefecture
Climate.
Sakura has a <a href="Humid%20subtropical%20climate">Humid subtropical climate</a> (Köppen "Cfa") characterized by warm summers and cool winters with light to no snowfall. The average annual temperature in Sakura is 14.8 °C. The average annual rainfall is 1428 mm with September as the wettest month. The temperatures are highest on average in August, at around 26.3 °C, and lowest in January, at around 4.5 °C.
Demographics.
Per Japanese census data, the population of Sakura increased rapidly from the 1960s to the 1980s, and at a lesser extent since.
History.
The area around Sakura has been inhabited since prehistory, and archaeologists have found numerous <a href="Kofun%20period">Kofun period</a> <a href="kofun">burial tumuli</a> in the area, along with the remains of a <a href="Hakuho%20period">Hakuho period</a> Buddhist temple. During the <a href="Kamakura%20period">Kamakura</a> and <a href="Muromachi%20period">Muromachi period</a>s, the area was controlled by the <a href="Chiba%20clan">Chiba clan</a>. During the <a href="Sengoku%20period">Sengoku period</a>, the Chiba clan fought the <a href="Satomi%20clan">Satomi clan</a> to the south, and the <a href="Later%20H%C5%8Dj%C5%8D%20clan">Later Hōjō clan</a> to the west. After the defeat of the Chiba clan, the area came within the control of <a href="Tokugawa%20Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a>, who assigned one of his chief generals, <a href="Doi%20Toshikatsu">Doi Toshikatsu</a> to rebuild <a href="Chiba%20Castle">Chiba Castle</a> and to rule over <a href="Sakura%20Domain">Sakura Domain</a> as a "<a href="daimy%C5%8D">daimyō</a>." Doi rebuilt the area as a "<a href="j%C5%8Dkamachi">jōkamachi</a>", or <a href="castle%20town">castle town</a>, which became the largest castle town in the <a href="B%C5%8Ds%C5%8D%20Peninsula">Bōsō region</a>. Under the <a href="Tokugawa%20shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a>, Sakura Domain came to be ruled for most of the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a> under the <a href="Hotta%20clan">Hotta clan</a>. In the <a href="Bakumatsu%20period">Bakumatsu period</a> the domain became a center for "<a href="rangaku">rangaku</a>" studies, centered on the <a href="Juntend%C5%8D">Juntendō</a> school of the doctor <a href="Taizen%20Sat%C5%8D">Taizen Satō</a> (1804 – 1872). The Juntendō and other educational institutions in Sakura contributed greatly to the <a href="Meiji%20Restoration">Meiji Restoration</a>. After the <a href="abolition%20of%20the%20han%20system">abolition of Sakura Domain</a>, the area eventually became part of Chiba Prefecture.
Sakura Town was one of several towns and villages created on April 1, 1889 under <a href="Inba%20District%2C%20Chiba">Inba District</a> with the establishment of the modern municipalities system. On March 31, 1954, Sakura achieved city status through merger of the neighboring municipalities of Usui, <a href="Wada%2C%20Chiba">Wada</a>, Nego, Yadomi, and Shizu.
Government.
Sakura has a <a href="mayor-council">mayor-council</a> form of government with a directly elected mayor and a <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> city council of 28 members. Sakura contributes three members to the Chiba Prefectural Assembly. In terms of national politics, the city is part of <a href="Chiba%209th%20district">Chiba 9th district</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Representatives%20of%20Japan">lower house</a> of the <a href="Diet%20of%20Japan">Diet of Japan</a>.
Economy.
Sakura is a regional commercial center and, due to its numerous train connections, a <a href="bedroom%20community">bedroom community</a> for nearby Chiba and Tokyo, with more than 24% of the population commuting, per the 2010 census.

Local attractions.
Sakura boasts a number of tourist attractions, including the large <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Japanese%20History">National Museum of Japanese History</a> located on the ruins of <a href="Sakura%20Castle">Sakura Castle</a>. Several samurai houses near the old castle are open to the public and are protected as <a href="Important%20Cultural%20Properties%20of%20Japan">Important Cultural Properties</a>. Other sights of interest include the <a href="Moto%20Sakura%20Castle">Moto Sakura Castle</a> (one of the <a href="Continued%20Top%20100%20Japanese%20Castles">Continued Top 100 Japanese Castles</a>.), <a href="Tsukamoto%20Sword%20Museum">Tsukamoto Sword Museum</a>, <a href="Sakura%20Museum%20of%20History%20and%20Folklore">Sakura Museum of History and Folklore</a>, <a href="Sakura%20City%20Museum%20of%20Art">Sakura City Museum of Art</a>, and the <a href="Sakura%20Juntendo%20Memorial%20Building">Sakura Juntendo Memorial Building</a>. Nearby is also the <a href="Kawamura%20Memorial%20Museum%20of%20Art">Kawamura Memorial Museum of Art</a>.
In 1994 on the 40th anniversary of the city's foundation a Dutch <a href="windmill">windmill</a> called "De Liefde" was erected by the Dutch <a href="millwright">millwright</a> company "Verbij Hoogmade BV" on the south-eastern shore of Lake Inba as a landmark of Sakura Furusato Square. The mill serving as a <a href="polder">polder</a> mill is named after the first Dutch sailing ship which landed on the Japanese shore in 1600. It is the only windmill of this type in Japan (a so-called "ground-sailer", which means a windmill whose sails reach almost down to the ground.
